response.raw:
Here is my attempt at the task, following the specified output format:

Involving Parents and Older Students to Facilitate Complex Play

1. Recruit parent volunteers to lead small group activities - Send home a volunteer sign-up sheet describing different activity stations (art, building, dramatic play, etc.) - Have parents sign up for time slots to facilitate the stations - Meet with parent volunteers to explain the learning goals and how to encourage focused, complex play 2. Partner with older grade levels for cross-age activities - Reach out to teachers in higher grades to arrange times for their students to visit - Have older students lead younger children in educational games, art projects, or building challenges - Provide clear instructions for the older students on how to engage the younger kids in complex play 3. Host a Family Game Night or Weekend Play Day - Invite families to come play educational board games or engage in building/art/dramatic play - Provide instructions at each station for how parents can facilitate more complex play - Encourage parents to follow their child's lead and ask open-ended questions to extend the play 4. Communicate the importance of complex play to families - Share articles and resources with parents on the cognitive and social benefits of focused, complex play - Provide examples of the types of play to encourage at home, along with question prompts - Update parents regularly on the complex play activities happening in the classroom so they can extend the learning at home
